titleproper.value:
Guide to the Cedric Belfrage Papers
                    <num>TAM.143</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Amy Meselson (1993)

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T18:36-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Cedric Belfrage, socialist, author, journalist, translator, and co-founder of the 
                <title render="italic">National Guardian</title>, was born in London in 1904. His early career as a film critic began at Cambridge University, where he published his first article in 
                <title render="italic">Kinematograph Weekly</title>(1924). In 1927 Belfrage went to Hollywood, where he was hired by the 
                <title render="italic">New York Sun</title>and 
                <title render="italic">Film Weekly</title>as a correspondent. Belfrage returned to London in 1930 as Sam Goldwyn's press agent. Returning to Hollywood, he became politically active, joining the Hollywood Anti-Nazi League, co-editing a left literary magazine, 
                <title render="italic">The Clipper</title>. Belfrage joined the Communist Party in 1937, but withdrew his membership a few months later. Thereafter, he maintained a friendly but critical relationship. In 1948, he wrote for and helped found the 
                <title render="italic">National Guardian</title>(later Guardian) to which he would remain affiliated until the 1960's. Belfrage was summoned in 1953 to appear before the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC), and in 1955, he was deported back to his native England. Belfrage then travelled to Cuba in 1961, and in 1962, travelled throughout South America finally settling in Cuernavaca, Mexico. In 1973, Belfrage returned to the U.S. for the first time since 1955, on a publicity tour for a new book. Belfrage continued to write extensively until his last years. He died in Mexico on June 21, 1990. 
                <emph render="bold">NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.</emph>

p.value:
Open for research without restrictions. 
                <emph render="bold">NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.</emph>

Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

<emph render="bold">Translations (all for Monthly Review Press, N.Y. & London, unless indicated)</emph>
                <list>
                    <item>Galeano: Guatemala Occupied Country, 1967.</item>
                    <item>Silen: We the Puerto Rican People, 1971.</item>
                    <item>Galeano: Open Veins of Latin America, 1973.</item>
                    <item>Galeano: Workers' Struggle in Puerto Rico, 1976.</item>
                    <item>Fraginals: The Sugarmill, 1976.</item>
                    <item>Selser: Sandino, 1981.</item>
                    <item>Galeano: Memory of Fire (translated 1983) Pantheon, 1985.</item>
                </list>

The Addendum contains correspondence of Cedric Belfrage, of his widow Mary Belfrage, a typescript of and unpublished autobiography by Cedrice, "Nine Lives of a Heretic," other writings by CB, including a typescript "The Jews and I," FIOA files obtained by Belfrage biographer Jennifer Palmer, correspondence and other materials relating to the Cuernavaca Belfrage home insofar as it served as a guest house for various leftists traveling abroad, and biographical information on Mary Belfrage.
